summary: This is a response brief filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team opposing the government's motion to not consolidate her civil and criminal appeals. The document argues the cases are related because the criminal perjury charges stem from the civil case, and unsealing deposition material would prejudice her ability to argue Fifth Amendment and Martindell issues in the criminal proceeding.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in both civil and criminal cases, appealing decisions and seeking to consolidate appeals to prevent unsealing of deposition material that could prejudice her criminal defense.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: Judge presiding over the civil case (No. 15-CV-7433) who issued an unsealing order that Maxwell is appealing.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Judge presiding over the criminal case (No. 20-CR-330) against Maxwell where she intends to argue Martindell and Fifth Amendment issues.

persons.name: Adam Mueller
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who signed and submitted this response brief, listed as counsel from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C.

persons.name: Ty Gee
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell listed as counsel on the response brief from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C.

persons.name: Nicole Simmons
persons.context: Person who certified service of the document filing on September 23, 2020.

persons.name: Jane Doe
persons.context: Anonymous plaintiff in Doe v. Indyke civil case alleging abuse and exploitation by Epstein and Maxwell as a minor.

connections.description: Mueller is listed as counsel for Maxwell and signed the legal brief on her behalf.
Gee is listed as counsel for Maxwell on the legal brief.
Jane Doe alleges in a separate civil case that Epstein and Maxwell abused and exploited her as a minor.
Both are attorneys from the same law firm representing Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Filing of Response Brief
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team files response brief opposing government's motion to not consolidate civil and criminal appeals.

events.title: Stay Granted in Doe v. Indyke
events.description: Court grants motion to stay civil case Doe v. Indyke to preserve integrity of criminal prosecution against Maxwell.

events.title: Maxwell Deposition
events.description: Deposition of Ghislaine Maxwell taken in April 2016, the transcript of which is subject to unsealing order.

locations: United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C. office)
keyFacts: The criminal case against Maxwell includes two perjury counts expressly based on her civil case testimony.
Discovery in the criminal case includes 90,000 pages of material from the civil case, comprising more than half of all discovery produced to Maxwell.
Maxwell's legal team argues that unsealing her April 2016 deposition would prejudice her ability to argue Martindell and Fifth Amendment issues in the criminal proceeding.
The government successfully moved to stay the Doe v. Indyke civil case to preserve the integrity of Maxwell's criminal prosecution, creating inconsistency according to Maxwell's team.
Maxwell's attorneys are attempting to consolidate appeals of civil unsealing order and criminal case issues to ensure all judges have access to relevant facts.
